explanation:
To decide whether the for-loop (for (i = 0; i <= VOLATILE_DISK_LOC_MAX; ++i)) is well-formed under the MISRA rule, the analyzer must know whether any called functions or objects used in the loop condition/step have persistent side-effects or can modify the loop counter. The following symbols are required and why:

- getenv
  - Called inside the loop body to set tmpdir when using the TMPDIR environment variable. Need the prototype/semantics to determine it does not modify the loop counter (i) or any object used in the loop clauses.

- stat
  - Called inside the loop body to inspect tmpdir. Need the prototype/semantics and knowledge of what it may modify (it writes into the provided struct stat pointer) to ensure it does not modify i or any object used in the loop clauses.

- struct stat (fields: st_mode, st_gid, st_uid)
  - The loop body inspects these fields of stat_buf to decide whether to break. The analyzer must know these are members of a local structure written by stat and not aliases of the loop counter or of objects used in the loop clauses.

- S_IWOTH, S_IWGRP, S_IWUSR
  - Bit-mask macros used on stat_buf.st_mode. The analyzer needs these macro definitions to understand the expressions in the body and to confirm they do not affect loop counter/clauses.

- getegid
  - Called in the loop body and used in a comparison with stat_buf.st_gid. Need the prototype/semantics to ensure it does not modify i or any objects used in the for-clause (and thus does not create persistent side-effects relevant to the MISRA second/third clause restrictions).

- geteuid
  - Same rationale as getegid: ensure it does not modify the loop counter or objects used in the loop clauses.

- typedef uint32
  - The loop counter i is declared as uint32. The analyzer needs the definition/width/type to confirm ++i in the third clause only modifies the single loop counter (and that ++i is a simple increment with no overloaded/hidden side-effects in C).

Rationale summary: MISRA requires the second clause to use only the loop counter and constants/flags (no objects modified in the loop body) and the third clause to modify only the loop counter. To prove compliance one must inspect all functions called in the loop body and any objects referenced by the loop condition/step to confirm none of them are modified (directly or indirectly) by the loop body functions and that the loop counter is the single control variable. The listed symbols provide the necessary prototypes, data-layout and macro semantics to make that determination.
